captions.text:
Of all the super cars from the 80's
there was nothing quite like

the Porsche 959. Built for group-B
homologation

the car was recognized as a
technological masterpiece.
One of the most advanced cars of its time.
With 450 horsepower from its twin turbo flat-six
the performance was extraordinary for the era. It would do close to 200 miles an hour.

But what remains most impressive today
is the

accuracy of it's vision for sports cars
of the future.

In a time where most cars were
carbuerated, where they had

drum brakes the 959's all-wheel-drive system
could selectively

change the torque split. The driver from
the cockpit
could adjust damper stiffness and ride height. It even had a tire pressure monitoring
system.

We take a lot of those features for
granted as they become the new norm,

but it makes us ask the question: what
can we expect

for the future? And for that we turn to
the Porsche 918.

though named after the legendary 917
racing car

it, its hybrid system, it's nearly 900
horsepower,

and its advanced all-wheel-drive system
could show the future
of sports cars just like the 959 did.
Just how fast is the 918?
0 RPM torque

and all-wheel-drive propels the 918 to
60 miles an hour in
2.4 seconds.

The quickest motor trend has ever
recorded.
The quarter-mile 10 seconds flat
at 145.2 miles an hour. How does that compare to the McLaren P1?
Let's see.
From 60 miles an hour
the 918's best braking performance took just 94 feet.

Putting it among the quickest stopping
cars ever tested.
Generating an average 1.12 G laterally
it's among one of the stickiest cars ever tested. Combine that with a balanced chassis,
the braking performance, incredible straight line acceleration,

and the car's ability to transfer torque
from wheel to wheel,
and you get a result that's the fastest figure 8 lap time

we've ever recorded and by a good
margin. At 22.2 seconds

the 918's lap is over half a second
faster than the previous leader.
And on a track where 1/10s make all the difference that lead
is simply jaw dropping.
The 918's performance is astounding today,

but like the 959 we're curious how
history will
view this car. So let's look back to the 959 with

Randy Pobst who remembers the sports car
climate of the 80's well.
Randy the 959
is an awesome car and a hugely important car for the 1980s.
You were racing cars at that time and racing them alot. What does this car mean vs
what you were driving? They're antiques. It was a whole other world.
The car's I was driving had no ABS.
My Volkswagen Golf club car
85 horsepower. Yep. It had CIS fuel injection,
no feedback, a primitive motion sensor.
It's crazy how advanced this car was for its time.
I mean nevermind the four-wheel-drive system which was revolutionary I mean this
thing had tire pressure monitoring,
it had ABS, it had sequential turbos, one would spool up before the other.
Titanium connector rods in 1985.

I mean that's space grade stuff. Yeah it's
almost like it was kind of a space
program level development for a four-wheeled automobile.
And 350 horsepower that was more than
double the standard 911 thanks to those turbos.
That's really kind of mind bending and today I have to
just consciously take myself back to the world that was then,
because now we're used to it right?
But not in 1980, what are we talking?
Back then 200 horsepower was a lot of horsepower.

What was really interesting is this wasn't a
race car
like the F40 was a racecar.

This was a GT Car that was built
to essentially do everything that's why
you have a snow
and gravel mode. That's why you have a granny gear is to drive through mud.
This was a car that was intended
to do everything at once.

All-purpose weapon. Yes! What's really
interesting about this car and the

is they show the roadmap for the
future.
Yeah I could see that. This car showed the next
30 years of automobile development
with
really accurately. And today's supercar's have all this technology.
The 918 is taking it to the next step. Yes.
The 959 is old school future tech.
In the 918 we have modern future tech.
What are your thoughts on this car? New school. [Carlos] New School?
I think this car is predicting the future.
The combination of the electric and gas and the efficient
the efficiency of making big power and
the efficiency of regenerating. Enery only changes
form and this car changes the energy back into a usable form and give it
right back to the wheels again. This car shows
that hybrids
have a lot of benefit with fuel economy but they can also be really cool

power adders they can be this
rechargeable
nitrous like feeling that gives you this really interesting
control in a lot of different ways on the axis.
Well there's a guage right on the side of your dash that says boost. That's not talking about turbos
this car doesn't have turbos.
That's electric boost. That's great it's like video games

each lap you get more boost when you
brake hard, when you
lift off the throttle the boost recharges

like it does in the video game. It's
crazy how cars actually replicate that. Does it? Yeah.
I don't play video games.
You drive cars. (laugh)
But the boost is new and the boost is really effective and electric.
And it can be
regenerating while we're driving. Yes.
And then the technology combies
the best of gas tech which
is aspirated and then you get that great

direct response from the engine. You get the
emotion of that exhaust though.
With the efficiency of having
the power. Yeah it's a fast car I mean you drive the Tesla and there
is no noise it's weird. Yeah you don't get this:
That's a beautiful thing (laugh).
Well it still sounds like a supercar. Yeah! It sounds fantastic.
This car is an indication of a future where you can have
a 600 horsepower 9000 rpm V8
or you can have 20 miles of all electric range,
where you can have the thrill of driving a sports car but also the economy.
If the future's like that sign me up.
I think the future's going to be great.
Of course we couldn't visit a

racetrack that's referred to as the
fastest road in the West
with the Porsche 918 without lapping it.

We looked and couldn't find a faster lap
time from a production car,
and that reality just begins to illustrate the new

paradigm we're seeing establish from
performance cars

of the future. They can be hybrids or
provide extra power to offset torque
deficiencies or simply be boost. The cars themselves no longer have to
be difficult to drive quickly
they can be balanced and friendly. They can be laden with technology,
but still feel utterly satisfying. They can give you everything.

title: 2015 Porsche 918 Spyder First Test: Fastest 0-60 Time Ever? Plus Porsche 959! - Ignition Ep. 109
